They Cleaned the Subway During Covid. Now They Will Earn Back Pay. A $3 million settlement will be divided among 452 underpaid workers employed at the height of the coronavirus pandemic, the city comptroller's office said. Susana Baez, who cleaned subway cars during the coronavirus pandemic, is among the workers who will benefit from the settlement. José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times

At the height of the coronavirus pandemic, Susana Baez would begin her shift at 1 a.m., scrubbing trash, vomit and human excrement from subway cars. She and her team, a largely immigrant work force contracted by private companies to clean New York City’s subway stations and train cars, often had to work without enough safety equipment, like gloves, she said. Many contracted Covid-19 on the job. “It was trauma,” Ms. Baez, 53, said in Spanish about the job, which she performed from 2020 to 2023, when her contract abruptly ended. Now, Ms. Baez and more than 450 other subway cleaners will split $3 million in back pay, after a multiyear investigation by the city comptroller found that they were grossly underpaid. The workers, who were employed by two private cleaning companies, earned around 25 percent less than they were owed, said Brad Lander, the city comptroller. His office sets the prevailing wage, or the typical rate, for certain types of public work. The cleaners made $16 to $18 an hour on average in the first years of the pandemic, without supplemental benefits, when $20 to $21 an hour was standard, Mr. Lander said. summary: A $3 million settlement will be divided among 452 underpaid workers employed during the coronavirus pandemic, according to the city comptroller's office. The workers, who were employed by two private cleaning companies, earned around 25 percent less than they were owed. The settlement includes largely immigrant workers who cleaned subway cars without adequate safety equipment. The cleaners made an average of $16 to $18 an hour in the first years of the pandemic without supplemental benefits, when the minimum wage was $15 an hour.
shortSummary: A $3 million settlement will be distributed to 45 underpaid subway cleaners, including Susana Baez, who worked during the coronavirus pandemic.

argos_summary: A $3 million settlement will be distributed among 452 underpaid subway cleaners in New York City, who worked during the coronavirus pandemic. These workers, including Susana Baez, were found to have earned about 25% less than the prevailing wage, receiving between $16 to $18 an hour instead of the standard $20 to $21.
